author: jschreiner22
title: Open Smart Contract Library
description: Currently, there aren’t strong enough incentives in place to make collaboration the obvious solution for projects building on Cardano.

f6_assessments.q0:
The proposal is well detailed, objective, clear, and has great potential to impact the community. For me, one of the most important core ideas is collaboration. This proposal is focused on developing a network between Cardano developers that will engage the community and create a loop of knowledge. To reinforce this, the author suggests payment to smart contract developers every time someone from the community makes use of their content to elaborate other ideas. 
The author was careful with mapping the risk and mitigation action for it but given the robustness of the project, I truly believe there are more risks he did not foresee. I strongly recommend conducting more brainstorming sessions with team members and people with knowledge of the subject, developing a risk matrix (impact vs probability), and coming up with more potential problems and mitigation actions that could solve them.
f6_assessments.q1:
Even though we can see a timeline that gives the idea of time, process, and deadline, I recommend the author elaborate a more detailed plan where he can focus on key milestones that he believes are important and demonstrate with more detail the phase durations.

Although the team seems to have a great connection with the challenge, I am not totally convinced that they are the best team to execute this project because there is no curriculum or details of who they are and what they had already done. 

For the cost, the number does not convince me because we can not see who will be responsible to execute what. I suggest the author to give us this idea and also create one more level of detailed activities.
f6_assessments.q2:
The auditability part did not convince me that the team is ready to elaborate it carefully and, in my opinion, this is crucial to create guarantees to the investor that he is allocating his money in the right place. 

Regarding the KPIs, they were well developed but KPIs without goals are not useful. I suggest the author revise this part and put some challenges for him and for the team aligning the pillar os KPIs: what, when and how much. 

In addition, KPIs must be breakdown to the team so everyone will be able to see their challenge and how the micro activities perform by then in daily basis will be able to support the whole project.

f6_assessments.q0:
The proposal aims to incentivice sharing of audited successful smart contracts. It is a continuation of a Fund7 proposal to help integrate smart contracts in off chain code. 

The proposal if successful could greatly increase the availability of Cardano smart contracts and thus pave the way for many new dApps and use cases. It first aims to provide smart contracts for DAOs, and it is probably wise to choose one type of contracts to begin with and be the go to place for that, then expand.
f6_assessments.q1:
The proposers have provided a tentative breakdown of activites in a timeline. The team will also collaborate with a firm specialized in Haskell development and with proven Plutus competence. 

However there is no whitepaper, nor any type of technical documentation on what is to be delivered and how. ClearContracts own Github was updated 2 years ago, but MLabs, whom they are collaborating with, seems to have many active repositories. 

Given that there is a proven partner, but no whitepaper and not that many hours of work requested funding for, it is quite hard to tell if they will be able to pull it off.

It would be good to provide more evidence of the feasibility of the proposal and also a proposed architecture in future proposals.
f6_assessments.q2:
The proposers have provided a timeline for the work which, while at very high level, gives some hard dates for evaluation.
The proposers have also provided a breakdown of hours per activity which corresponds somewhat to the milestones in the timeline.

While one could wish for more detail both in the work breakdown and in the milestones, there is information which can be compared to the progress of the project.

In future proposals a breakdown in smaller activities with the necessary competencies listed and the hours estimated would be helpful.

f6_assessments.q0: The proposer realizes that it is necessary to create a platform that allows Cardano developers to upload smart contracts and earn profit when other developers and/or projects use them. This smart contract library will create a platform where the experienced members give the obvious solution for projects building on Cardano. The project is drafted for 3 quarters in 2022 but then can be prolonged for the next years, widened in many various countries. The solution will increase the number and quality of Cardano open source projects, increase the number of contributors, and increase the number of open source tools/frameworks.
f6_assessments.q1: The team to develop the project includes the business developer, the engineer. However, they do not yet describe in detail the experience and skill of the participants. The budget is drafted clearly. It is logically divided into 700 hours including planning and research, building Smart Contract Upload Portal, Integration with Clarity Protocol, Extension for Community Contribution, Testing, Spec/Documentation Writing, Optimizations/Audit Preparation. The proposer has clear plan for 3 coming quarters, including planning and researching, building initial smart contract templates internally, integrating initial templates with Clarity Protocol for testing and refinement, extending capabilities to include open collaboration, spec/Documentation Writing, community rating system, auditing. It is applicable and can be successful. The proposer realizes that the large challenge for this project is to build the smart contract templates in a way that they can be easily integrated into different projects that may have different structures. To address this issue, they begin by building smart contracts that are tailored to DAOs built using our Clarity DAO Tooling Protocol. By this way, the organizations have a similar core structure and will be able to more easily build interoperable software. As the process of uploading smart contracts to the library becomes more refined and efficient, they will begin broadening the scope of projects that contribute to the protocol.
f6_assessments.q2: This project has clear goal for the whole process. After 1 month, they expect to create a standard process to turn audited Plutus smart contracts into templates on our platform. After 3 months, other developers can be able to upload their own templates and receive rewards. After 6 months, they broaden the scope of the smart contract library beyond DAOs, building a credibility metric to give precedence to formally audited contracts. The Proposal is described clearly and the solution method is easily understood.

f6_assessments.q0:
The solution statement is relevant and very related to the challenge of lack of incentives, and both are clearly written and detailed. Additionally, the idea seems to connect many parties to collaborate with by allowing projects in the ecosystem to access templates used previously in another project. The proposal has direct impact into Cardano projects creating a loop of leverage impacting all the ecosystem by the idea of increasing the number of open-source tools/frameworks.
The idea of paying developers when their contracts are used is a very smart way to incentive even more people to collaborate and to create high quality material. One challenge cited was well addressed, but I am not sure that the proposer has done this sufficiently. So, I recommend making a bigger effort of forecast challenges with a risk matrix of probability and impact. This activity will make the team explores even more the scenarios and preparing themselves to overcome issues.
f6_assessments.q1:
The feasibility statement could be a little bit more solid. A timeline was created giving the idea of deadline and process, but I recommend using a more detailed plan with milestones and phases duration.
Some details of the team could be explored since we don’t know if they are capable of execution. Even though the proposal statement written give the idea of experience and connection with the mission.
For the funds, I recommend having more levels of breakdown to show how the cost was built and guarantee a full understanding of the number, how it will be achieved, and the impact may result.
f6_assessments.q2:
The Auditability part, in my opinion, is the most important part to present a good investment and satisfy the investor, creating reliable relationship. I don’t think the team have explored it as much at its potential by not showing credibility.
Despite of KPI’s were established and seems to reflect the process of the project execution, no goals was created to be a success comparison during the monitoring project. Raw numbers with no comparison have no value.
The goals cited are more like objectives statements that can reflect the aim of each phase but is not an evaluation form (e.g., how will I prove the addition of the ability for other developers to upload their own templates and receive rewards during and after the third month?). I recommend unfolding goals and metrics to simply guiding efforts and new paths to redress if necessary.

f6_assessments.q0: open source development is obviously quite important for any strong decentralized ecosystem.
f6_assessments.q1: I've seen multiple proposals say they have partnered with Mlabs and then fail to give any inforamtion about who the actual proposers are. How can I judge their implimentation ability if they do not declare who will be working on this. It could be that Mlabs will do all the software development, but it is not so clear to me what this means and why the lack of transparency for the proposers.
f6_assessments.q2: The show metrics they would like to meet, but not how they will meet them. Or even the difficulties in meeting such metrics. Again, this with Mlabs doing the engineering may make sense, but I would hope for more descriptions of the technical challenges for such a technical proposal.

f6_assessments.q0: The challenge is to encourage open source development, and this proposal outlines a problem of incentives for open source developers. The proposal is to provide financial incentives, but it is not clear where the financial incentives come from. If other developers must pay to use the platform, then it is not encouraging "open source", it becomes a pay to use service. It creates a financial incentive to develop and contribute to the platform, but a disincentive for developers to use the platform (assuming they, or someone, must pay for the service)
f6_assessments.q1: The team is experienced, and previously funded through catalyst. It is likely the proposal will be implemented and developed as described. However, the long term financial sustainability and funding of developer incentives remains unclear in this proposal as it is written.
f6_assessments.q2: The auditable KPI's are listed in the proposal, but clear targets (actual numbers for each KPI) are not listed. It is not clear how the community can audit the overall concept of adding financial incentives for developers (both + and - financial incentives) will bring about a net + to the ecosystem.

f6_assessments.q0: This proposal is for creating an open source smart contract library. This would help new developers who are unfamiliar with the Haskell based Plutus protocol access template that could accelerate Dapp creation on the Cardano Blockchain. This is directly in line with the challenge: Open Source Development Ecosystem.
f6_assessments.q1: There is a roadmap with defined milestones quarter by quarter. There is a specified amount of $56,000 requested, but not with a breakdown in how it will be allocated like in many other proposals, which is helpful for transparency. However, there is an existing website / domain ( https://clearcontracts.io/ ) referenced in the proposal, which indicated that there is some capital already invested in this effort. Outside of the profile name, I do not see any information on the proposer’s skillset or background. There is however a listed partnership with MLabs (A Haskell, Rust, Blockchain and AI consultancy). Link: ( https://builtoncardano.com/m-labs ) This partnership is documented in both the proposal and on MLabs website. If the proposer is directly involved in building this project, I would respectfully ask the proposer to please consider adding some information on his / her experience, and perhaps a Linkedin profile to future proposals.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposal lists milestones for each quarter and projected workhours required to execute this proposal. There is also a section of this proposal dedicated to auditability. I think there is enough information to audit the progress of this proposal.

f6_assessments.q0: Open contracts are at the heart of most contracts...from NFT games transacting on in-game currencies and their NFTs, to maintaining a rental system of ships around the globe. This would help many projects by providing a leaping off place...and starting point...and then sharing with the community to improve bugs, security issues, etc.

...and their website is professional, clean, and organized. I am just wondering why they did not put more of their experience on their proposal: so that is my one star deduction.

f6_assessments.q2: Information about MLabs can be leveraged here in place of information perhaps not provided. Consequently, the proposal can address future challenges because is a start botton for other projects or at least is a way to facilitate them. The proposal is clear when explains about how the project would cause impact in our community but I think the proposers could expose better about how the phases of the project would happen.
f6_assessments.q1: The proposal presents the step by step of the project. I think the proposer could explain better these steps besides only present them. f6_assessments.q2: The proposal gives a explanation about the problem and the solution that makes sense to solve it. In addition, it makes clear the roadmap with the milestones and deadlines it wants to achieve. The KPI's were really well chosen and pointed in the proposal. f6_assessments.q0:
The impact of this proposal, should it be implemented in full and extended to ALL smart contracts created for many different purposes using Plutus, would be phenomenal and mirror the functionality of github (or gitcoin on Eth) on the Cardano blockchain. A repository of audited smart contracts written in Plutus would be priceless for the entire Cardano ecosystem. And rewarding programmers who create desirable code is laudable.

This proposal directly answers to the Integrations portion of this challenge and more than adequately answers the following guiding question of this challenge:

*What applications deliver the highest amount of value with the least amount of technical sophistication?

The proposal identifies a problem of integration and lack of a smart contract Cardano-based repository which needs to be solved, clearly articulates how it will add value to the Cardano ecosystem in time and lays out in minute detail the key metrics and goals of the as aligned with the challenge objectives. And I will write again that remuneration for proficient coders who develop highly desirable smart contracts is a terrific incentive and deserves its plaudits.

However I must point out two concerns I have: one, that though the language of the proposal is altruistic and collaborative, it may come to pass that the inherent differences in structure of the dapps that are created on the Cardano blockchain preclude the library from being as relevant as it could be. Just as dapps found and coded different solutions to the concurrency problems of the eUTxO model they encountered in Fall 2021, they may find that the library of smart contracts is not applicable to their dapp due to their chosen structure. Finally, I wanted to highlight that initially the repository being created will be self-serving in that it will contain smart contracts already created by Clear Contracts and MLabs (like CC Bot, Escrow Service, etc.) and may be a way to prevent future DAO creating dapps from forking code to develop competitors (like DAOStack, DAOHaus, Aragon, and Colony are competitors on Eth) without compensation to the original developers. Also, starting with smart contracts using tooling created by Clarity DAO just for Clarity DAO is a very smart first step, and I hope the extent of the project does not stop there. Hence, I raise a minor concern that the following impact goal will not be achieved:

*The proposal is able to scale to address future challenges.
f6_assessments.q1:
The proposer's collaboration with MLabs, its previously funded proposal of no code, audited smart contracts, and work to develop Clarity DAO smart contracts like CC Bot and Escrow Service (which will be tested on testnet soon) provide ample evidence (references, links, etc.) of relevant skills and experience needed to implement the proposal.

Though the proposal does not identify the manner, the type and number of team members required, the budget is outlined clearly and broken down into identifiable items, as is the timeline. 

The budget seems a reasonable estimate of time to achieve the set goals and the proposal offers a realistic timetable to complete the work entirely, with a reasonable estimate of at least a beta library in Q3 of 2022 that will have open collaboration. Further, it is clear and thoughtful and details the steps needed in ascending order to create the smart contract library, with a proper 50 hours allocated to planning and research, which is in my opinion, a good idea.

The proposal is sensible and lays out the outcomes of the proposal in a clear and well defined manner.
Finally, Clear Contracts has considered challenges and risks relevant to a successful implementation and will hopefully be able to overcome any obstacles to a full and open collaborative library of smart contracts that is used by many different dapps.
f6_assessments.q2:
This proposal is clear and its timeline and milestones are well defined. Other than the caveats I proffered in the Impact section of this assessment regarding Clarity DAO (and one final caution below) , everything in this proposal seems clear, auditable and thoughtful. There is a eminently achievable roadmap with milestones and a time horizon for achievement. As well, Clear Contracts (the proposer) understands the problem this would solve and displays genuine understanding of the issues that may hinder collaboration in contributing to and using the library. Starting with Clarity DAO smart contracts is a great first step and hopefully it enables the proposer to anticipate problems that may occur when moving to other different types of smart contracts (not just those using Clarity DAO tooling).

Finally, the only issue I may be concerned about regarding Clarity and Auditability is when the proposer expects the following KPI's to be relevant and what numbers would indicate success:

KPI’s: # of templates used, # of templates created, # of developers contributing, # of projects using templates.

It may be helpful to assess these at 3-month intervals and stating so would add more color to the project.

f6_assessments.q0:
As a Senior Developer myself I know that one of the most important Software engineering principles is reusability of the code and this proposal addresses that aspect. I, therefore, strongly agree that this solution will not only promote reusability but also increase rewarding culture to those developers who provide open source smart contracts that other future developers/teams might need for their projects. 

This proposal will help the talented developers pool to contribute more to Cardano and could catalyze the development process of projects that are launching on Cardano, hence, I strongly believe that this proposal, if funded, will add a lot of value to the Cardano open source ecosystem. 

The short term. Mid term and long term goals of the proposal are in alignment with open source settings, as all of them are promoting the developer participation via open sourcing the smart contracts as templates and adding to the proposal team platform. Therefore, i strongly agree that this proposal effectively addresses the challenge.
f6_assessments.q1:
The proposer has provided the information that for business development the clear contracts team and for engineering MLabs will be responsible. There are no public links available for the team members who will work on this project. I have gone through the website of Clear contract, where they have a couple of their products listed, but I could not find any technical expertise (e.g. open source projects on GitHub). 

Therefore, I am assuming that they are relying totally on experience of developers on MLabs, which is well known for having a great set of plutus/haskell developers contributing to different projects such as Liqwid Labs, Ardana etc. So, I am pretty satisfied with the technical expertise needed to achieve this proposal goals.

Additionally, They have already a project funded in Fund7 , no code, audited smart contracts, and this proposal is a continuation to that one, and which will add the ability to extend their platform to support smart contracts upload from the community developers.

The timeline is split quarterly and each quarter functionalities are given. The total budget is provided, which seems ok when I compare with the number of Development/Engineering hours provided in detail. Nevertheless, For community sake, I would have preferred that the team provided more detail such as how many developers will work on it and what would be their approximate hourly rate. 
Nevertheless, the timelines are realistic and with all that the team has previously done, they have credibility in the Cardano ecosystem, hence I fully agree that this proposal will be highly likely to be successfully implemented.
f6_assessments.q2:
I strongly agree that the project is highly auditable. The KPIs can be easily tracked by GitHub as the project will be open source, although for non technical community members it might be a little challenging to find that detail from the proposal writeup, so I see some room for improvement in the proposal writeup. 

The quarterly timelines provide a good insight on the milestones and time horizon for this project. Personally, I find the 6 month goal as the most important one as this is an absolute must in order to avoid unaudited smart contracts on-chain.

The community could already see that the long term vision of this proposal will be to build credibility metrics to reward audited smart contracts (very important in my opinion) and in the short to mid term the proposal will focus on the functionalities set provided in development hours.

f6_assessments.q0:
The F8 challenge seems to prioritize a variety of creative ways to ease the onboarding of new ETH users, and I think a subsidized 1-1 approach is a great way approach. 
Specifically, you mention a lack of interest from projects to engage Cardano as a viable blockchain. I also see this as a roadblock, and while anyone who knows Cardano well understands this is not the case, the general public doesn't seem to. Any proposal that can help improve Caranos brand awareness while also helping with on-boarding is a win in my books.

Another strength of this proposal is the commitment to an authentic, honest approach. While this seems obvious as something important, I think it can be forgotten or not prioritized enough. Making integrity AND simplicity as key pillars is a great way to signal to your team what this is all about!
f6_assessments.q1:
The importance of building out the Cardano ecosystem in order to attract the much needed "sea" of new and skilled technical personnel is captured in this proposal by showcasing a relevant set of experience with its NFT guild. Great to see quality proposals being submitted by involved community members, who also show a network of like minded people (who have also submitted proposals. I think this sort of collaboration among our community is exactly what is needed and will provide an underestimated amount of synergies, especially overtime as Cardano scales up!!

Adding to the synergy (and feasibility) the of this proposal is the balanced mix of both technical and artistic experience (see below).

An NFT from the collection was the first one to be sold through a smart contract, minutes after the Alonzo HFC. It also was the first sale through a smart contract on Cardano to pay residuals (i.e. royalties) to artists on resales of their works.

Award-winning filmmakers, film and animation directors, app and game developers. In 2021 they moved into the web3 economy granting new life to one of their projects in the form of an NFT collection on Cardano.
f6_assessments.q2:
This proposal did a good job at measuring both on the subjective return on intent (# of visits, # of consultant sessions), while also considering the more objective and measurable result (# of projects onboarded). Also thought it had aggressive, but attainable goals.

The reason I did not give a 5 for audibility was that while it did cover the goals and metrics for the short and medium term (3 months, after 6 months), it would be good to have a better idea of what long term success looks like. I understand this space moves lighting fast and it is hard to predict long term goals, but would be helpful to at-least show a few thoughts.

Excellent proposal! Something i am very interested in myself! Well done.

f6_assessments.q0: The proposal aims to offer a platform to collect several smart contracts, with the double benefits of generating revenues for the programmer who wrote the contract and the possibility for users to utilize that contract for their projects without the need to code
f6_assessments.q1:
The team has not been presented in any way, although important partnerships have been put in place, such as a collaboration with MLabs, which is a very important point for the credibility of the project.
The website linked in the proposal outlines well the objectives of the project.
What I see missing is how the user would use the platform to understand what's the right smart contact to exploit for their projects and how the tool on the website would help them to create a new custom made smart contract without the need of programming: is it like a Marlow playground with puzzle like objects?
I see also a contraddiction with 'open source' smart contract, which is not totally open source if some user would pay to utilize it
f6_assessments.q2:
The development time has been broken down effectively, showing that the major efforts will be dedicated to Build Smart Contract Upload Portal and writing specs and documentation.
The budget requested is 56000 USD, which seems realistic given the 700 h estimated time for project delivery. 
I would have liked to see a flowchart of the whole conceptualised process from a smart contract developer point of view and from a user of an already written smart contract point of view.
Moreover, it is not clear to me how the DAO would receive funds ongoing. Will a portion of the fees paid by the users for the smart contract organisation end in a dedicated staking pool?

f6_assessments.q0:
The proposal is a future platform where developers would be able to share their smart contract templates, and if another developer or project uses this template, the author will be payed. That's overall a good idea and it falls in the challenge categoriy well enough. I personaly like this aproach because it allows for easier time when writing the smart contracts because you would be able to just see if there isn't a template already for what you're trying to do. As a developer myself I'm in love with this idea.
The metrics are pretty relevant for measuring adoption which is a good and safe way to go. One thing I lacked is the actual number though. It would be nice if they had put how many people they expect to have at some point, or how many templates created. Scaling is again related to adoption, because the more people start using their platform, the more the whole project would scale and the authors have already mentioned this effect, but there are no concrete steps to ensure this success.
The proposal definitely adds a missing puzzle piece to the ecosystem and would be a great addition and help the growth of Cardano.
My only real concern is there wasn't any mention on how they're going to make themselves known. They have a great idea, but I didn't find any budget for marketing which is important as well. And if nobody knows about your great product, they can't use it. The projects that have started to form a community from day one are really doing well, so my recomendation for the authors would be to start building their community from day one as well.
Overall I really like this proposal, and I plan on testing it out if it gets voted in. Good luck!
f6_assessments.q1:
Nothing too much to say about the feasibility of the project except that it has a good breakdown of the cosss in hours, which is the best way to do it att least from what I've seen done, because it allows the CA to look at the hourly rate and as a developer I can do a rough estimation about if the given time seems legit to me for the work that needs doing. It also gives me the oportunity to calculate the hourly rate which is decent compared to other proposals and compared to the guidelines provided by the project catalyst.
The team members are well known, and I've seen a couple of different proposals in this and previous funds by the MLabs teams and I have been able to verify their given credentials and skillset and I concur they have all the necessary skills to get the job done in the most efficient manner.
The roadmap is decent and the timeframe given seems to match the work that needs doing, but the milestones could be a bit better detailed. 
The technical aspects of the proposal could have been done a bit better, because as a developer and considering this is an open source project I'd be really interested (an I'm sure I'm not the only) about the technologies used and at least the open source repository linked where all the work will go in. 
Overall I believe this is a feasible solution and the team has proven their worth overtime, but the feasibility part of the proposal is a bit rough around the edges and needs some polishing and details.
f6_assessments.q2:
Project tracability could be difficult because there's no link provided to a github repository or another platform, where the development would be done. This doesn't allow for easy access by someone like me interested in following along and maybe helping (as a developer) to grow the platform and the ecosystem. A discord or a telegram channel with announcements would have been nice, just to mention and even if they have one, I didn't find it and I'm not sure if the project is auditable as it is now.
The metrics and KPIs mentioned have no count to them which is problematic, because they set no standard for themselves, which means any number of templates used between 1 - 10000 would be achieving their goals as specified in this proposal. I do realize they plan on having more than one smart contract template, but how many would be good enough for the project to be self sustained, would be a really good metric to have.
I like the general idea of the roadmap and considering there's a team of people, it's a reasonable estimation of the timeframe. The problem is well defined and the proposers have a good aproach to finding the solution which is also well enough explained.

f6_assessments.q0: I think the use of smart contracts eliminates the need for middlemen, which greatly reduces operational costs. I find that smart contracts help increase transparency and reduce operational costs. If implemented properly, they can also increase operational efficiency and reduce administrative costs. Besides, I see that Smart Contract is based on the blockchain system, so it cannot be modified and interfered with. Once the Smart Contract is written, if you want to change it, the only way is to rewrite a new contract. Immutability is a great advantage, but in some cases can be a disadvantage.
f6_assessments.q1: I think smart contracts are an essential component for many platforms. Because the main purpose of smart contracts is to simplify business transactions between parties by eliminating the middlemen involved in traditional business processes. These contracts are intended to reduce payment delays, risk of error, and the complexity of a conventional contract without compromising authenticity and reputation. The main special advantage is that it allows reliable execution of transactions without the need for intermediaries. Therefore, the feasibility of this project is good but there will be high competition. Because today, smart contracts are much closer to our daily lives than one might think. Many blockchain platforms are using them in their operations and different programming languages ​​are used to write smart contracts.
f6_assessments.q2: I think many other factors also affect the effectiveness of smart contract audit, such as communication between the project team and the audit team. However, businesses should work to identify the challenges of smart contract audits to improve their efficiency in leveraging smart contracts. Smart contract auditing can be a promising tool to improve smart contract functionality. What seems impenetrable has some security holes in it. The cost of smart contract testing can vary significantly depending on the platform or tool you choose to use. But besides that I think there has never been a piece of software that did not contain bugs or security holes and smart contracts are no different. Therefore, it is necessary to have a clear control mechanism to avoid the worst from happening.

f6_assessments.q0:
I like to go through all the aspects met that define this challenge and assess one by one how well this proposal does in fitting into the challenge problem statement.

How can we guide the growth of a vendor neutral ecosystem?
The proposal answers this question well by making the use of smart contracts more democratic – anyone can download the template for a small fee and I assume it is built by the well-known proposer’s own team of Haskell and Plutus experts as well as Plutus Pioneers maybe or people on Technical Discord. This perfectly solves the problem if it can be done in a way that is useful – meaning making the template work for the use case of the buyer.
How can we build a common identity and increase awareness on Cardano projects?
The proposal allows other people to add to the proposers initial templates and mentions that the ecosystem will have a positive feedback loop by the competition created in offering money to the templates that users actually want. In terms of creating a common identity this is a start.
How can we increase the discoverability and the commercial adoption of our projects?
This aspect is also well answered by the proposal as the best smart contract developers will converge to earn fees (and maybe build their reputation also) by sharing their templates. This will allow everyone to learn who the skilled Plutus developers are and more good projects can be discovered using this knowledge.
How can we increase the degree of collaboration across different projects?
Similar to the discoverability, by having Plutus developer become better known, we can collaborate more. I like the idea because of this.

How can we lower the barriers and increase open participation to our ecosystem?
Many people mention that it is very difficult to develop on Cardano and find programmer with Haskell and Plutus skill. Even though a template cannot do very complicated, specialized task, it will lower the cost and allow some simple transaction like minting token so I think that it does actually help a lot to fill the request of the challenge.

How can we provide equal opportunities to all projects no matter the size?
Same here, offering good quality templates and ready-to-use smart contracts for the most common use case will lower the bar for new development teams.

There is no precise direction provided by the challenge that suits the proposal “to a tee”but in my opinion it answers all the questions very well. “Introduce common standards and processes and incentivize their adoption across projects” is met nicely by actually giving the incentive of earning a fee for talented developers so if it can be implemented it will be a very close fit.
f6_assessments.q1: The proposer partners with well-known MLABs and F10 and thereby deserves some Kudo and also has a website that informs the assessor about what they do. This "namedropping" however should have been backed up with the Linkedin profiles of the team members who will work on this project. The budget breakdown is very good with all the detail required, detailing nicely how the funds will be used. The project roadmap is not as clear and is only given by each quarter of 2022 with a headline like "Plan and research" but not giving the detail I like to know how it can actually be turned into a working solution. This is a pity as it is possible that the team is so strong that they can do it, we just do not know from the information that is given and that is all I have to judge.
f6_assessments.q2: Making the audit for progress and success of this project will be very hard, so I have to say that "I disagree" with "sufficient". If you are the auditor responsible for making payment to the project how can you verify a milestone like "Integrate initial templates with Clarity Protocol for testing" as there is no mention of the formal method, whether this is happening in the public domain or what kind of report is made to share the progress. I understand that for complex development it is not easy to share until you have working code, but as this is in the Open Source and Open Standard category, more transparency should have been possible for the proposers. At least breaking down the time into months instead of quarters, having a graphic for the implementation or mention the tools for reporting and project management or saying how the well-known partners ensure that the proposers do their job should have been there.

f6_assessments.q0: This proposal effectively addresses the challenge's goals. It is a continuation of an F7 funded project "No code, audited Smart Contracts". It suggests a common ground- a library - for developers where their work will be appreciated and get compensated too.  Having one common platform for all the smart contracts developed frees the hands of users to choose what they need without looking around, without duplicating, wasting time or money.  The authors clearly stated the problem and the solution to the problem that leads in favor of cardano ecosystem. Although this is straight forward, it is not clear to me how the proposers will attract the developers to add their contracts in the library.  How will they gather these developers?  It is clear that there is a monetized incentive for smart contracts to be added in the library, but the intermediate step is not clear.  The impact for cardano ecosystem is clear and can definitely benefit users and the ecosystem.
f6_assessments.q1: The project team is not clearly identified in the proposal although proposers sound from their words that they can implement the project successfully.  The proposers will collaborate with others to complete it but there is not reference to how many will perform the tasks and which tasks, and what's their expertise is. The road map is described is three blocks and each block includes the work to be done during that time.  I had to assume with caution that each block represents two months (and maybe I am mistaken) of the timeline.  Having a clear timeline instead of Qs helps.  In regards to costs, the total of working hours is provided for each task.  It remains unclear how many people will perform the tasks. There are 700 working hours that correspond to 29 full days give and take.  It remains unclear to me how the project will be completed in regards to timeline/people.
f6_assessments.q2: The KPIs needed to achieve the project are clearly stated and can be followed to verify successful completion of the project. I have difficulty though connecting the roadmap and the timeline with the KPIs for reasons previously stated.  This is a very useful project for the cardano ecosystem and beyond, but questions are raised in regards to feasibility, or rather the proposers could have given more details on implementation.  It feels as if there is a beginning and an end with a gap in the middle, although I support the proposal.

solution: Create a platform that allows Cardano developers to upload smart contracts and earn profit when other developers and/or projects use them.
experience: We are currently partnered with MLabs to build Clarity, a DAO tooling protocol on Cardano.  This involves building the beginnings of a smart contract library, which we are proposing to extend in order to allow outside parties to contribute.
